questions.stem: A researcher notices that participants in a treatment study are improving over time, but suspects this may be due to natural maturation rather than the intervention. This represents a threat to:
questions.explanation: Maturation is a threat to internal validity—the ability to conclude that the IV caused changes in the DV. When participants improve due to developmental processes rather than treatment, we cannot attribute improvement to the intervention. Control groups help address this threat.

questions.stem: A study using college students enrolled in Psychology 101 finds a significant effect for a cognitive intervention. Concern about whether these findings apply to the general adult population represents a threat to:
questions.explanation: External validity concerns generalizability of findings beyond the specific study conditions. Population validity specifically asks whether results generalize to other populations. College students differ from the general population in age, education, SES, and other variables.

questions.stem: In a study comparing two therapy approaches, the researcher discovers that many participants in the control condition sought additional treatment outside the study. This represents which threat to internal validity?
questions.explanation: When control participants seek treatment elsewhere, the distinction between treatment and control conditions breaks down. This is treatment contamination—control participants are no longer truly untreated, making it difficult to attribute differences (or lack thereof) to the experimental treatment.

questions.stem: A researcher finds that participants who completed a lengthy depression study showed improvement, but 40% of the most severely depressed participants dropped out before completion. This illustrates:
questions.explanation: Experimental mortality (attrition) threatens internal validity when dropout is systematic rather than random. If more severe cases drop out, completers will appear improved not due to treatment effectiveness but due to losing the most impaired participants from the sample.

questions.stem: A study demonstrates strong internal validity through random assignment and rigorous controls, but uses a highly artificial laboratory task. Critics argue the findings may not apply to real-world settings. This illustrates the:
questions.explanation: There is often a tradeoff between internal and external validity. Tight experimental control enhances internal validity (causal conclusions) but may reduce ecological validity (generalizability to real settings). Field studies have the opposite pattern—more realistic but less controlled.

questions.stem: Which of the following are threats to INTERNAL validity? Select all that apply.

options.text: History—external events occurring during the study
Regression to the mean—extreme scores becoming less extreme

questions.explanation: History, testing, instrumentation, and regression to the mean all threaten internal validity by providing alternative explanations for observed changes. Narrow stimulus sampling threatens external validity (generalizability across situations/stimuli), not internal validity.

questions.stem: Random assignment to conditions helps control for which threats to internal validity? Select all that apply.

options.text: Regression artifacts when selecting extreme groups

questions.explanation: Random assignment equalizes groups at baseline, controlling for selection bias, selection interactions, and regression (if all participants, not just extreme scorers, are assigned). It doesn't prevent history (affects all participants) or differential attrition (happens after assignment).

questions.stem: Which factors threaten EXTERNAL validity? Select all that apply.
questions.explanation: External validity threats involve interactions that limit generalizability: treatment works only for this sample (selection), in this setting, at this time (history), or because participants know they're being studied (reactivity). Maturation is an internal validity threat.

questions.stem: A researcher wants to maximize external validity. Which strategies would help? Select all that apply.

options.text: Use representative sampling from the target population
Conduct the study in naturalistic settings
Replicate findings across different populations and settings
Use heterogeneous rather than homogeneous samples

questions.explanation: External validity is enhanced by representative sampling, naturalistic settings, replication across contexts, and sample heterogeneity. Double-blind designs enhance internal validity (control bias) but don't directly affect generalizability.

questions.stem: The Hawthorne effect, where participants change behavior because they know they're being observed, threatens which types of validity? Select all that apply.

options.text: External validity (lab findings may not generalize)
Construct validity (measuring attention vs. the construct)

questions.explanation: Hawthorne effect threatens multiple validity types: internal (improvement due to attention, not treatment), external (effects occur only in observed conditions), construct (confounding treatment with observation effects), and ecological (artificial lab awareness). It doesn't affect statistical accuracy.

questions.stem: Match each threat to the correct type of validity it primarily affects.

rows.text: Participants selected for extreme scores regress toward the mean
Results apply only to participants who volunteer for studies
A major news event during the study affects all participants
Treatment works in the lab but not in clinical practice

questions.explanation: Regression to the mean and history are internal validity threats (alternative explanations). Volunteer sample limits generalizability to population (who volunteers?). Lab-to-practice gap is ecological validity (does it work in real settings?).

questions.stem: Match each research design feature with the validity concern it primarily addresses.
questions.explanation: Random assignment addresses selection (internal). Representative sampling addresses population validity (external). Control groups rule out alternative explanations like history, maturation (internal). Multi-site replication tests across settings (external).

questions.stem: For each research scenario, select ALL validity threats that apply.

rows.text: Study of cognitive decline in elderly—no control group
Pre-post depression study during pandemic lockdown
Study selects participants with highest anxiety scores
Treatment study where therapists know who is in treatment vs control

questions.explanation: Elderly cognition without control: can't separate age-related decline from other factors (maturation). Pandemic study: external events confound treatment (history). Extreme score selection: natural regression looks like improvement. Non-blind design: experimenter expectations can influence outcomes.

questions.stem: Select ALL ways each design feature enhances study validity.
questions.explanation: Double-blind: controls both experimenter and participant expectations. Placebo: isolates active treatment effect from expectancy. Intent-to-treat: analyzes all randomized participants regardless of completion (addresses attrition). Matching: reduces error variance by equating groups on key variables.

questions.stem: Internal validity refers to the extent to which we can conclude that changes in the {{blank1}} were caused by the {{blank2}}. The primary method for establishing internal validity is {{blank3}}. External validity concerns whether findings {{blank4}}.

options.text: generalize to other people, settings, and times

questions.explanation: Internal validity: DV changes caused by IV (not confounds). Random assignment is the primary method to establish internal validity. External validity: generalizability across populations, settings, times. Note: random selection helps external validity; random assignment helps internal.

questions.stem: Campbell and Stanley identified several threats to internal validity. {{blank1}} refers to events outside the study that affect outcomes. {{blank2}} refers to natural developmental changes over time. {{blank3}} occurs when participants selected for extreme scores show apparent change. {{blank4}} refers to participants leaving the study differentially across conditions.
questions.explanation: Campbell and Stanley's classic threats: History = external events. Maturation = developmental changes. Regression = extreme scores moving toward mean. Mortality/attrition = differential dropout. These are the foundational concepts for understanding internal validity.

questions.stem: A researcher conducts a therapy study with no control group, selecting the most severely depressed patients from a clinic waitlist. After 12 weeks, significant improvement is observed. The researcher concludes the therapy is effective.

options.text: Regression to the mean (extreme score selection)
No control group to rule out alternative explanations
Random assignment to treatment vs control
Select participants across full range of severity

questions.explanation: This pre-experimental design has multiple internal validity threats: regression (extreme selection), maturation (natural course), history (no control comparison). Improvements: add control group, random assignment, don't select on extremes. Sample size addresses power, not validity.

questions.stem: A highly controlled laboratory study demonstrates that a brief mindfulness intervention reduces experimentally-induced stress in undergraduate psychology students. The researchers want to implement this in corporate wellness programs.

options.text: Lab stressors differ from workplace stress
Brief intervention may not produce lasting effects
Strong internal validity but limited external validity
The treatment effect is not real
Selection bias in the original study
Assess longer-term outcomes with real stressors
Increase the sample size of original study

questions.explanation: The lab study has good internal validity (controlled) but questionable external validity. Before implementation: test across populations (employees), settings (workplace), and with ecological outcomes (real stress, lasting effects). This is the internal-external validity tradeoff.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL factors that represent threats to INTERNAL validity.
questions.passage: When evaluating research studies, methodologists consider various threats to valid conclusions. [When participants improve simply because they've been tested before, this is called testing effects]. [Using a convenience sample from a single university limits the study]. [Natural developmental changes during a long study can explain improvement without treatment]. [The researcher's enthusiasm may inadvertently influence participants' responses]. [A major economic recession during the study period affected all participants' stress levels]. [The study results may not apply to clinical settings].

highlightableSegments.text: When participants improve simply because they've been tested before, this is called testing effects
Using a convenience sample from a single university limits the study
Natural developmental changes during a long study can explain improvement without treatment
The researcher's enthusiasm may inadvertently influence participants' responses
A major economic recession during the study period affected all participants' stress levels
The study results may not apply to clinical settings

questions.explanation: Internal validity threats: testing (practice effects), maturation (developmental changes), experimenter bias (influencing responses), history (recession). External validity threats: convenience sampling (population), lab-to-clinic applicability (ecological). Know the difference.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that correctly describe EXTERNAL validity.
questions.passage: External validity is an important consideration in research design. [External validity concerns whether findings generalize beyond the specific study conditions]. [Random assignment to conditions is the primary method for establishing external validity]. [Population validity asks whether results apply to people other than the study sample]. [Ecological validity concerns whether results apply in real-world settings]. [External validity is more important than internal validity in basic research]. [Replication across different settings and populations strengthens external validity].

highlightableSegments.text: External validity concerns whether findings generalize beyond the specific study conditions
Random assignment to conditions is the primary method for establishing external validity
Population validity asks whether results apply to people other than the study sample
Ecological validity concerns whether results apply in real-world settings
External validity is more important than internal validity in basic research
Replication across different settings and populations strengthens external validity

questions.explanation: Correct: generalizability definition, population validity, ecological validity, replication enhances. Incorrect: random assignment establishes INTERNAL validity; internal validity is typically prioritized in basic research (must know effect is real before asking if it generalizes).

questions.stem: Arrange these research phases in the correct order for establishing both internal and external validity of a treatment.

items.text: Conduct tightly controlled efficacy trial (RCT) to establish causal effect
Replicate in different controlled settings with different populations
Conduct effectiveness trial in real-world clinical settings
Examine moderators: for whom and under what conditions does treatment work?
Implement in community practice with ongoing monitoring

questions.explanation: Research progresses from internal to external validity: first establish causal effect (RCT), then replicate, then test in real settings (effectiveness), then identify boundary conditions, finally disseminate. This is the efficacy-to-effectiveness pipeline.

questions.stem: Arrange these events in a study chronologically, and identify which represents the greatest threat to internal validity.

items.text: Participants are recruited and baseline measures taken
Participants are randomly assigned to treatment or control
30% of control group participants drop out
Post-treatment measures are collected from remaining participants

questions.explanation: The differential attrition (30% control dropout) is the greatest threat. It occurs after randomization, so assignment can't fix it. If dropouts differ from completers (they often do), groups are no longer equivalent, and apparent treatment effects may reflect who remained rather than treatment efficacy.

questions.stem: A researcher selects students with the lowest 10% of reading scores for an intervention study. Examine the pre-post data pattern.
questions.question: The improvement in the treatment group is partially attributable to which validity threat?
questions.explanation: When participants are selected for extreme scores (lowest 10%), regression to the mean is expected—extreme scores move toward the population average on retest even without intervention. The 'statistical expectation' line shows expected regression. True treatment effect is improvement BEYOND regression.

questions.stem: A researcher examines attrition patterns in a 12-month treatment study for depression.
questions.question: What validity concern does this attrition pattern raise?

options.text: The improvement in depression scores is solely due to effective treatment
Differential attrition may bias results—sicker patients may have dropped out
The control group had too few participants at baseline

questions.explanation: Control group has much higher attrition (52% vs 25%), likely because untreated depressed patients dropped out. If the most depressed dropped out, remaining completers look better—not because of treatment effect but due to biased survival. This is differential attrition/experimental mortality.

questions.stem: Categorize each threat as primarily affecting INTERNAL validity or EXTERNAL validity.
questions.explanation: Internal threats (alternative explanations): regression, testing, history, mortality. External threats (generalizability limits): population×treatment interaction, volunteer bias, ecological validity, narrow stimuli. The key question: Internal = 'Is the effect real?' External = 'Does it apply elsewhere?'

questions.stem: Categorize each design feature by its PRIMARY purpose.
questions.explanation: Internal: random assignment, control groups, blinding, standardization. External: representative sampling, random selection, naturalistic settings. Multi-site replication serves both—confirms effect is real AND generalizes. Understanding which features serve which validity type is crucial.
